data.name: title
data.content: A Different Way to Look at Word Problems

data.name: para
data.content: In pre-algebra, we do not rush to solve word problems. First, we understand the story and translate it into math language.

data.content: word-problems.png

data.name: image
data.content: word-problems.png

data.name: bullet
data.content: Real objects appear in the story

data.name: bullet
data.content: These objects represent quantities

data.name: bullet
data.content: We do not calculate yet

data.name: title
data.content: Abstract Model

data.name: para
data.content: Instead of real objects, we use simple blocks and symbols. This step is called abstraction.

data.name: image
data.content: word-problems.png

data.name: bullet
data.content: Known quantities are shown as blocks

data.name: bullet
data.content: Unknown quantities are shown as X and Y

data.name: bullet
data.content: Both sides represent equal totals

data.name: title
data.content: Math Expression

data.name: para
data.content: The abstract model is written as a math expression, such as 3 + X = 4 + Y. This represents the story in math form.

data.name: bullet
data.content: Word problem is not solved yet

data.name: bullet
data.content: The goal is translation, not calculation

data.name: bullet
data.content: This is the heart of pre-algebra thinking

data.name: quote
data.content: First translate the story. Solving comes later.

data.name: author
data.content: — Pre-Algebra Mindset
